India's economic reputation took a hit last week.

You know, as the baby boomers hit their 60s, social service agencies are being stretched to their limits to help such a large and growing group of people.
Does the foundation feel some of that pinch, trying to help these folks too?
Well, absolutely.
You know, there is never enough to make up for all of the injustices that have happened to a lot of these artists.

Some of it self-inflicted, but a great deal of it, inflicted just by virtue of - here's one of my favorite stories, is a lady by the name of LaVerne Baker, who wrote a song called Roll with me Henry, all right baby.
Roll with me Henry.
And it was done by a singer by the name of Georgia Gibbs.
Now Georgia Gibbs had all of the pop radio stations, the 50,000 watters, where her product was being played, but LaVerne Baker was relegated to rhythm and blues stations.
And so the question came, well was she hurt by this?
I mean, jeez, she got her records played, she sold a million copies.
But it was about, she probably could have sold 10 million copies if she had had the same amount of exposure as Georgia Gibbs.

And so that's part of the equation, is that we had these wonderful artists who, in some instances back in the day, as my sons would say, they couldn't even have their pictures on the album covers because the marketing people thought that it might hurt their sales.
Now how is the foundation able to help them?
What do you do for them?
Well, what we do most of all is to get them to come to our event.
They are just so glad that somebody remembers them, somebody cared about them.
Then we have been able to get them medical services when they have run out of funds, and that takes us to a political thing.
Now we start talking about universal health care, we could go on that for a long, long time.
But you find that young lady who was a member of the Supremes, who died in poverty, and couldn't get, you know, all the things that she needed.
Mary Wells, who died of cancer, Little Junior Parker.
All of these people have found that the needs that they have have been serviced in a great measure by the Rhythm and Blues Foundation.
And because we don't want to embarrass them, we don't say to them come to our event and we're going to hold you up to the light and tell them all the tragedies and stuff that you've had.
But along with these awards comes a monetary gift, and I think that oftentimes gets overlooked.
That these are not just awards that put on the mantelpiece, and hang on the wall, these are something you can take to the bank.

Let me tell you something.

Republican Bob Inglis served six terms in the House, representing 4th district of the state of South Carolina.
He's now the executive director at republicen - that's E-N, for energy - .org.
Mr. Inglis, thanks for being with us.
Thanks, Scott.
Great to be with you.
During your second term in the House, you became passionate about climate change, I think it's safe to say.
What convinced you this was a pressing issue?
Well, it was really the love of my son that started it.
You know, I was my first six years in Congress saying that climate change was hooey, Al Gore's imagination.
I hadn't looked into it at all.
All I knew was he was for it, and therefore, I was against it.
But I was out of Congress for six years and then ran again in '04.
My son was voting for the first time.
And so he came to me and said, dad, I'll vote for you.
But you're going to clean up your act on the environment.
So that was the first of three steps.
Second step was going to Antarctica and seeing the evidence in the ice core drillings.
Third step was really a spiritual awakening, another science community trip, Great Barrier Reef, snorkeling with an Aussie climate scientist.
And I found it rather inspiring.

So I came home and introduced the Raise Wages, Cut Carbon Act of 2009 - probably not the best idea in the midst of the Great Recession, in perhaps the reddest district in the reddest state in the nation.
What arguments do you make to Republican conservatives about climate that you think might be most resonant?
What we talk about is being climate realists and energy optimists.
We should be realistic about the science.
And then let's also be energy optimists, realize the power of free enterprise to fix this problem.
If we would just put the cost on the fuels, then the free enterprise system would sort this out.
And also, at the same time, we should eliminate all subsidies for all fuels.
Then the innovation that would come from the free enterprise system would be exciting.
I think a lot of Americans would say, well, of course we know the price of energy.
It's the price we pay for a tank of gas.
No, there are hidden costs, of course.
It's - basically what economists say is what you need to do is internalize the negative externalities, reveal those hidden costs.
Make it so that at the meter, at the pump, we see the true cost.
Wouldn't the established energy companies go nuts?
It depends on who they are, of course.
If it's a natural gas company or a company that has significant natural gas assets, they'd be excited about this if they thought it was going to be - really going to happen.
That's our challenge at republicen.org, is convincing particularly some natural gas folks that really, this could happen, that the fossil fuels could become accountable.
And, of course, when that happens, coal would fall much faster to the competitive pressure of natural gas.
And the natural gas companies would make a lot more money off of their product.
Is it the end-all?
No, it isn't.
Natural gas still has CO2 emissions.
But it's 50 percent less emissions than coal.
So that's an example of how fixing the economics would then fix the environmental consequence.
Mr.
Inglis, as you survey this field of Republican candidates for president, do you see and hear any who express your viewpoint on the climate change?
It's been helpful to hear what John Kasich has said on the topic.
Jeb Bush has had some fairly positive things to say.
I think even the exchange between Marco Rubio and Chris Christie in one of the debates was helpful in that they were trying to move away from the label of the denier.
And so what we think would be effective is helping them to change the question.
Currently, if a Republican is asked in front of a very conservative crowd, do you believe in climate change or, is it a fact, an affirmative answer ostracizes them from the audience.
But if we can phrase that question differently - can free enterprise solve climate change?
- then they can answer that question in the affirmative in front of the reddist-meat crowd because of course we conservatives believe that free enterprise can solve problems you don't even have.
Bob Inglis is executive director at republicen.org.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Great to be with you, Scott.
Thank you.
